thread.title_full: Win-win deal for Minotaur, OZ | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Valerina Changarathil
title: Win-win deal for Minotaur, OZ | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The
text:
MINOTAUR Exploration will assess and test shareholder OZ Minerals’ copper prospects around the Prominent Hill mine in the Gawler Craton.
The co-exploration agreement covering the Mt Woods area between the company that discovered the Prominent Hill deposit in 2001 and OZ, which has developed it since 2005, is being described as a win-win for both parties.
OZ Minerals has carried out extensive greenfields exploration work in the region around the Prominent Hill mine camp.
OZ Minerals, which has a 4.47 per cent interest in Minotaur, believes scope exists for the database to reveal further opportunities.
“Given its resources are currently directed towards identifying and acquiring advanced mineral assets, OZ Minerals invited Minotaur Exploration to partner with it in an endeavour to identify, assess and test prospects which could lead to new copper discoveries,” Minotaur managing director Andrew Woskett said.
“The Minotaur team is very excited at the prospect of re-entering the tenements of its origins, particularly in partnership with OZ Minerals,” he said.
OZ Minerals managing director Andrew Cole said: “This is a win-win for OZ Minerals and Minotaur. We get Minotaur’s proven expertise in exploration and analysis and they get access to our vast repository of data.”
OZ Minerals will reimburse Minotaur for up to 80 per cent of its time costs expended on the research work, a task expected to take several months.
A $3 million budget funded 50/50 will allow for initial “truthing of prospects” to achieve proof of concept, with Minotaur as operator. A joint venture could subsequently be formed with Minotaur holding a 20 per cent interest.
The Mt Woods area represents classic iron-oxide copper-gold prospective terrain.
Minotaur shares closed 8.7 per cent higher on 7.5c yesterday, while OZ stock was 4.4 per cent lower at $3.90.
